div.p: This element belongs conceptually within WRITING PRODUCTION . It addresses texts that we do not have today for some reason or another. Describes any mishaps or disasters that happen on the road to publication. If the manuscript burned, or flew out the stage coach window; if the work was unfinished; if the publishers went bankrupt and lost her manuscript; if nobody knows what became of it: all of these incidents can be recorded here. Encloses statement; for use with or without also using rDestructionofWork. PNONSURVIVAL can be used of actual destruction (a manuscript casualty of fire or flood, a single surviving copy seen but since lost) or absence of knowledge (she claimed to have written plays, but none appears to have survived). One attribute modifies this element: TYPEOFNONSURVIVAL, with values for accident, and unknown.

This element can apply to texts that are currently lost, or to evidence that the author deliberately lost them because she did not want her writing to survive (see RDESTRUCTIONOFWORK). It also can apply to post-publication or post-circulation destruction, such as Sappho's poems being burned/suppressed by monks (see RPENALTIES) or the burning of her works with the Library at Alexandria (see RDESTRUCTIONOFWORK).

If a text encountered a mishap but was still brought to publication, or if a particular copy was destroyed but the text survived in other versions then use PMANUSCRIPTHISTORY and/or RDESTRUCTIONOFWORK, not PNONSURVIVAL. For example: a fire at the publishers destroys her manuscript, but there are other copies, and the book is eventually published.
